Bibliographic details for the Source Text
William Shakespeare 1564-1616
The Late and much admired Play, called Pericles, Prince of Tyre.
With the true Relation of the whole Historie, adventures, and fortunes of the said Prince:
As also, The no lesse strange, and worthy accidents in the Birth and Life, of his Daughter Mariana
As it has been divers and sundry times acted by his Maiesties Servants, at the Globe on the Banck-side.
By William Shakespeare.

Imprinted at London for Henry Gosson, and are
to be sold at the signe of the Sunne in Pater-noster row &c. 1609.
Preliminaries and introductory matter omitted.

Play details
Pericles, Prince of Tyre. Genre: Tragi-comedy. Date first published: 1609. Date first performed: 1606-1608.

sp.l: To sing a Song that old was sung,
From ashes, ancient Gower is come,
Assuming man's infirmities,
To glad your ear, and please your eyes:
It hath been sung at Festivals,
On Ember eves, and Holidays:
And Lords and Ladies in their lives,
Have read it for restoratives:
The purchase is to make men glorious,

l.foreign: Et bonum quo Antiquius eo melius:

sp.l: If you, born in those latter times,
When Wits more ripe, accept my rimes;
And that to hear an old man sing,
May to your Wishes pleasure bring:
I life would wish, and that I might
Waste it for you, like Taper light.
This Antioch, then Antiochus the great,
Built up this City, for his chiefest Seat;
The fairest in all Syria.
I tell you what mine Authors say:
This King unto him took a Peer,
Who died, and left a female heir,
So buxom, blithe, and full of face,
As heaven had lent her all his grace:
With whom the Father liking took,
And her to Incest did provoke:
Bad child, worse father, to entice his own
To evil, should be done by none:
But custom what they did begin,
Was with long use, accounted no sin;
The beauty of this sinful Dame,
Made many Princes thither frame,
To seek her as a bedfellow,
In marriage pleasures, playfellow:
Which to prevent, he made a Law,
To keep her still, and men in awe:
That who so asked her for his wife,
His Riddle told, not lost his life:
So for her many of wight did die,
As yon grim looks do testify.
What now ensues, to the judgment of your eye,
I give my cause, who best can justify.

div1.stage: Exit. Enter Antiochus, Prince Pericles, and followers.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: Young Prince of Tyre,
The danger of the task you undertake.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: I have ( Antiochus ) and with a soul emboldened
With the glory of her praise, think death no hazard,
In this enterprise.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Music bring in our daughter, clothed like a bride,
For embracements even of Ioue himself;
At whose conception, till Lucina rained,
Nature this dowry gave; to glad her presence,
The Senate house of Planets all did sit,
To knit in her, their best perfections.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: See where she comes, apparelled like the Spring,
Graces her subjects, and her thoughts the King,
Of every Virtue gives renown to men:
Her face the book of praises, where is read,
Nothing but curious pleasures, as from thence,
Sorrow were ever razed, and testy wrath
Could never be her mild companion.
You Gods that made me man, and sway in love;
That have inflamed desire in my breast,
To taste the fruit of yon celestial tree,
(Or die in the adventure ) be my helps,
As I am son and servant to your will,
To compass such a bondless happiness.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: Prince Pericles.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: That would be son to great Antiochus.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Before thee stands this fair Hesperides,
With golden fruit, but dangerous to be touched:
For Death like Dragons here affright thee hard:
Her face like Heaven, enticeth thee to view
Her countless glory; which desert must gain:
And which without desert, because thine eye
Presumes to reach, all the whole heap must die:
Yon sometimes famous Princes, like thyself,
Drawn by report, adventurous by desire,
Tell thee with speechless tongues, and semblance pale,
That without covering, save yon field of Stars,
Here they stand Martyrs slain in Cupids Wars:
And with dead cheeks, advise thee to desist,
For going on deaths net, whom none resist.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Antiochus, I thank thee, who hath taught,
My frail mortality to know itself;
And by those fearful objects, to prepare
This body, like to them, to what I must:
For Death remembered should be like a mirror,
Who tells us, life is but breath, to trust it error:
I will make my Will then, and as sick men do,
Who know the World, see Heaven, but feeling woe,
Gripe not at earthly joys as erst they did;
So I bequeath a happy peace to you,
And all good men, as every Prince should do;
My riches to the earth, from whence they came;
But my unspotted fire of Love, to you:
Thus ready for the way of life or death,
I wait the sharpest blow ( Antiochus )
Scorning advice; read the conclusion then:
Which read and not expounded, it is decreed,
As these before thee, thou thyself shalt bleed.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Of all said yet, mayst thou prove prosperous,
Of all said yet, I wish thee happiness.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: Like a bold Champion I assume the Lists,
Nor ask advise of any other thought,
But faithfulness and courage.

sp.p: The Riddle.

l.hi: I am no Viper, yet I feed
On mothers flesh which did me breed:
I sought a Husband, in which labour,
I found that kindness in a Father;
He is Father, Son, and Husband mild;
I, Mother, Wife; and yet his child:
How they may be, and yet in two,
As you will live resolve it you.

sp.l: Sharpe Physic is the last: But O you powers!
That gives heaven countless eyes to view men's acts,
Why cloud they not their sights perpetually,
If this be true, which makes me pale to read it?
Fair Glass of light, I loved you, and could still,
Were not this glorious Casket stored with ill:
But I must tell you, now my thoughts revolt,
For he is no man on whom perfections wait,
That knowing sin within, will touch the gate.
You are a fair Viol, and your sense, the strings;
Who fingered to make man his lawful music,
Would draw Heaven down, and all the Gods to hearken:
But being played upon before your time,
Hell only danceth at so harsh a chime:
Good sooth, I care not for you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Prince Pericles,
For that is an Article within our Law,
As dangerous as the rest: your time is expired,
Either expound now, or receive your sentence.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: Great King,
Few love to hear the sins they love to act,
It would braid yourself too near for me to tell it:
Who has a book of all that Monarchs do,
He is more secure to keep it shut, than shown.
For Vice repeated, is like the wandering Wind,
Blows dust in others eyes to spread itself;
And yet the end of all is bought thus dear,
The breath is gone, and the sore eyes see clear:
To stop the Air would hurt them, the blind Mole casts
Coped hills towards heaven, to tell the earth is thronged
By man's oppression, and the poor Worm doth die for it:
Kings are earths Gods; in vice, their law is their will:
And if Ioue stray, who dares say, Ioue doth ill:
It is enough you know, and it is fit;
What being more known, grows worse, to smother it.
All love the Womb that their first being bred,
Then give my tongue like leave, to love my head.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Heaven, that I had thy head; he has found the meaning:
But I will gloze with him. Young Prince of Tyre,
Though by the tenor of your strict edict,
Your exposition misinterpreting,
We might proceed to counsel of your days;
Yet hope, succeeding from so fair a tree
As your fair self, doth tune us otherwise;
Forty days longer we do respite you,
If by which time, our secret be undone,
This mercy shows, we will joy in such a Son:
And until then, your entertain shall be
As doth befit our honour and your worth.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: How courtesy would seem to cover sin,
When what is done, is like an hypocrite,
The which is good in nothing but in sight.
If it be true that I interpret false,
Then were it certain you were not so bad,
As with foul Incest to abuse your soul:
Where now you both a Father and a Son,
By your untimely claspings with your Child,
(Which pleasures fits a husband, not a father)
And she an eater of her Mothers flesh,
By the defiling of her Parents bed,
And both like Serpents are; who though they feed
On sweetest Flowers, yet they Poison breed.
Antioch farewell, for Wisdom sees those men,
Blush not in actions blacker than the night,
Will show no course to keep them from the light:
One sin (I know) another doth provoke;
Murder is as near to Lust, as Flame to Smoke:
Poison and Treason are the hands of Sin,
Aye, and the targets to put off the shame,
Then least my life be cropped, to keep you clear,
By flight, I will shun the danger which I fear.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: He hath found the meaning.
For which we mean to have his head:
He must not live to trumpet forth my infamy,
Nor tell the world Antiochus doth sin
In such a loathed manner:
And therefore instantly this Prince must die,
For by his fall, my honour must keep hie.
Who attends us there?

sp.speaker: Thali.
sp.l: Doth your highness call?

sp.speaker: Antio.
sp.l: Thaliard, you are of our Chamber, Thaliard,
And our mind partakes her private actions,
To your secrecy; and for your faithfulness,
We will advance you, Thaliard:
Behold, here is Poison, and here is Gold:
We hate the Prince of Tyre, and thou must kill him;
It fits thee not to ask the reason why?
Because we bid it: say, is it done?

sp.speaker: Thali.
sp.l: My Lord, it is done.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p:
Enough. Let your breath cool yourself, telling
your haste.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: My Lord, Prince Pericles is fled.

sp.speaker: Antio.
sp.p:
As thou wilt live fly after, and like an arrow shot
from a well experienced Archer hits the mark his eye doth
level at: so thou never return unless thou say Prince Pericles is dead.

sp.speaker: Thal.
sp.p:
My Lord, if I can get him within my Pistols
length, I will make him sure enough, so farewell to your
highness.
sp.l: Thaliard adieu, till Pericles be dead,
My heart can lend no succour to my head.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Let none disturb us, why should this change of thoughts
The sad companion dull eyed melancholy,
By me so used a guest, as not an hour
In the days glorious walk or peaceful night,
The tomb where grief should sleep can breed me quiet,
Here pleasures court mine eyes, and mine eyes shun them,
And danger which I feared is at Antioch,
Whose arm seems far too short to hit me here,
Yet neither pleasures Art can joy my spirits,
Nor yet the others distance comfort me,
Then it is thus, the passions of the mind,
That have their first conception by misdread,
Have after nourishment and life, by care
And what was first but fear, what might be done,
Grows elder now, and cares it be not done.
And so with me the great Antiochus,
Gainest whom I am too little to contend,
Since he is so great, can make his will his act,
will think me speaking, though I swear to silence,
Nor boots it me to say, I honour,
If he suspect I may dishonour him.
And what may make him blush in being known,
He will stop the course by which it might be known,
With hostile forces he will overspread the land,
And with the stint of war will look so huge,
Amazement shall drive courage from the state,
Our men be vanquished ere they do resist,
And subjects punished that never thought offence,
Which care of them, not pity of myself,
Who once no more but as the tops of trees,
Which fence the roots they grow by and defend them,
Makes both my body pine, and soul to languish,
And punish that before that he would punish.

div1.stage: Enter all the Lords to Pericles.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: Joy and all comfort in your sacred breast.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.p:
And keep your mind till you return to us
peaceful and comfortable.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Peace, peace, and give experience tongue,
They do abuse the King that flatter him,
For flattery is the bellows blows up sin,
The thing the which is flattered, but a spark,
To which that spark gives heat, and stronger
Glowing, whereas reproof obedient and in order,
Fits kings as they are men, for they may err,
When seignior sooth here does proclaim peace,
He flatters you, makes war upon your life.
Prince pardon me, or strike me if you please,
I cannot be much lower than my knees.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: All leave us else: but let your cares overlook,
What shipping, and what ladings in our haven,
And then return to us, Hellicans thou hast
Moved us, what seest thou in our looks?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: An angry brow, dread Lord.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: If there be such a dart in Princes frowns,
How durst thy tongue move anger to our face?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: How dares the plants look up to heaven,
From whence they have their nourishment?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Thou knowest I have power to take thy life from thee.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I have ground the Axe myself,
Do but you strike the blow.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Rise, prithee rise, sit down, thou art no flatterer,
I thank thee for it, and heaven forbid
That kings should let their ears hear their faults hid.
Fit Counsellor, and servant for a Prince,
Who by thy wisdom makes a Prince thy servant,
What wouldst thou have me do?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
To bear with patience such griefs as you
yourself do lay upon yourself.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Thou speakest like a Physician Hellicanus,
That ministers a potion unto me:
That thou wouldst tremble to receive thyself,
Attend me then, I went to Antioch,
Whereas thou knowest against the face of death,
I sought the purchase of a glorious beauty,
From whence an issue I might propagate,
Are arms to Princes, and bring joys to subjects,
Her face was to mine eye beyond all wonder,
The rest hark in thine ear, as black as incest,
Which by my knowledge found, the sinful father
Seemed not to strike, but smooth, but thou knowest this,
It is time to fear when tyrants seems to kiss.
Which fear so grew in me I hither fled,
Under the covering of a careful night,
Who seemed my good protector, and being here,
Bethought what was past, what might succeed,
I knew him tyrannous, and tyrants fear
Decrease not, but grow faster than the years,
And should he do it, as no doubt he doth,
That I should open to the listening air,
How many worthy Princes bloods were shed,
To keep his bed of blackness unlaid ope,
To lop that doubt, he will fill this land with arms,
And make pretence of wrong that I have done him,
When all for mine, if I may call offence,
Must feel wars blow, who spares not innocence,
Which love to all of which thyself art one,
Who now reprovedest me for it.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Alas sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Drew sleep out of mine eyes, blood from my cheeks,
Musings into my mind, with thousand doubts
How I might stop this tempest ere it came,
And finding little comfort to relieve them,
I thought it princely charity to grieve for them.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p:
Well my Lord, since you have given me leave to speak,
Freely will I speak, Antiochus you fear,
And justly too, I think you fear the tyrant,
Who either by public war, or private treason,
Will take away your life: therefore my Lord, go travel for
a while, till that his rage and anger be forgot, or till the Destinies
do cut his thread of life: your rule direct to any,
if to me, day serves not light more faithful than
I will be.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I do not doubt thy faith.
But should he wrong my liberties in my absence?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: We will mingle our bloods together in the earth,
From whence we had our being, and our birth.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Tyre I now look from thee then, and to Tharsus
Intend my travail, where I will hear from thee,
And by whose Letters I will dispose myself.
The care I had and have of subjects good,
On thee I lay, whose wisdoms strength can bear it,
I will take thy word, for faith, not ask thine oath,
Who shuns not to break one, will crack both.
But in our orbs will live so round, and safe,
That time of both this truth shall never convince,
Thou showedest a subjects shine, I a true Prince.

sp.p:
So this is Tyre, and this the Court, here must I kill
King Pericles, and if I do it not, I am sure to be hanged at
home: it is is dangerous.
Well, I perceive he was a wise fellow, and had good
discretion, that being bid to ask what he would of the
King, desired he might know none of his secrets.
Now do I see he had some reason for it: for if a
king bid a man be a villain, he is bound by the indenture
of his oath to be one.
Hushed, here comes the Lords of Tyre.

div1.stage: Enter Hellicanus, Escanes, with other Lords.

sp.speaker: Helli.
sp.p:
You shall not need my fellow-Peers of Tyre,
further to question me of your kings departure: his sea
led Commission left in trust with me, does speak sufficiently
he is gone to travail.

sp.speaker: Thaliard.
sp.l: How? the King gone?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p:
If further yet you will be satisfied, (why as it
were unlicensed of your loves) he would depart? I will give
some light unto you, being at Antioch.

sp.speaker: Thal.
sp.l: What from Antioch?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p:
Royal Antiochus on what cause I know not,
took some displeasure at him, at least he judged so: and
doubting lest he had erred or sinned, to show his sorrow,
he would correct himself; so puts himself unto the Ship-man's
toil, with whom each minute threatens life or
death.

sp.speaker: Thaliard.
sp.l:
Well, I perceive I shall not be hanged now,
although I would, but since he is gone, the Kings seas
must please: he scaped the Land to perish at the Sea, I will
present myself. Peace to the Lords of Tyre.
Lord Thaliard from Antiochus is welcome.

sp.speaker: Thal.
sp.p:
From him I come with message unto princely
Pericles, but since my landing, I have understood your Lord
has betake himself to unknown travails, now message
must return from whence it came.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p:
We have no reason to desire it, commended
to our master not to us, yet ere you shall depart, this we
desire, as friends to Antioch we may feast in Tyre.

div1.stage: Exit. Enter Cleon the Gouernour of tharsus, with his wife and others.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: My Dyoniza shall we rest us here,
And by relating tales of others griefs,
See if it will teach us to forget our own?

sp.speaker: Dion.
sp.l: That were to blow at fire in hope to quench it,
For who digs hills because they do aspire?
Throws down one mountain to cast up a higher:
O my distressed Lord, even such our griefs are,
Here they are but felt, and seen with mischiefs eyes,
But like to Groves, being topped, they higher rise.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: O Dioniza.
Who wanteth food, and will not say he wants it,
Or can conceal his hunger till he famish?
Our tongues and sorrows to sound deep:
Our woes into the air, our eyes to weep.
Till tongues fetch breath that may proclaim
Them louder, that if heaven slumber, while
Their creatures want, they may awake
Their helpers, to comfort them.
I will then discourse our woes felt several years,
And wanting breath to speak, helpe me with tears.

sp.speaker: Dyoniza.
sp.l: I will do my best Sir.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: This Tharsus over which I have the government,
A City on whom plenty held full hand:
For riches strewed herself even in her streets,
Whose towers bore heads so high they kissed the clouds,
And strangers never beheld, but wondered at,
Whose men and dames so jetted and adorned,
Like one another's glass to trim them by,
Their tables were stored full to glad the sight,
And not so much to feed on as delight,
All poverty was scorned, and pride so great,
The name of help grew odious to repeat.

sp.speaker: Dion.
sp.l: O it is too true.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: But see what heaven can do by this our change,
These mouths who but of late, earth, sea, and air,
Were all too little to content and please,
Although they gave their creatures in abundance,
As houses are defiled for want of use,
They are now starved for want of exercise,
Those palates who not yet too savours younger,
Must have inventions to delight the taste,
Would now be glad of bread and beg for it,
Those mothers who to noursle up their babes,
Thought naught too curious, are ready now
To eat those little darlings whom they loved,
So sharpe are hungers teeth, that man and wife,
Draw lots who first shall die, to lengthen life.
Here stands a Lord, and there a Lady weeping:
Here many sink, yet those which see them fall,
Have scarce strength left to give them burial.
Is not this true?

sp.speaker: Dion.
sp.l: Our cheeks and hollow eyes do witness it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: O let those Cities that of plenty's cup,
And her prosperities so largely taste,
With their superfluous riots hear these tears,
The misery of Tharsus may be theirs.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Where is the Lord Governor?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Here, speak out thy sorrows, which thee bringest
in haste, for comfort is too far for us to expect.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
We have descried upon our neighbouring
shore, a portly sail of ships make hitherward.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: I thought as much.
One sorrow never comes but brings an heir,
That may succeed as his inheritor:
And so in ours, some neighbouring nation,
Taking advantage of our misery,
That stuffed the hollow vessels with their power,
To beat us down, the which are down already,
And make a conquest of unhappy me,
Whereas no glories got to overcome.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
That is the least fear.
For by the semblance of their white flags displayed, they
bring us peace, and come to us as favourers, not as foes.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.p:
Thou speakest like hymns untutored to repeat,
Who makes the fairest show, means most deceit.
But bring they what they will, and what they can,
What need we leave our grounds the lowest?
And we are half way there: Go tell their General we
attend him here, to know for what he comes, and whence
he comes, and what he craves?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I go my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: Welcome is peace, if he on peace consist,
If wars, we are unable to resist.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Lord Governor, for so we hear you are,
Let not our Ships and number of our men,
Be like a beacon fired, to amaze your eyes,
We have heard your miseries as far as Tyre,
And seen the desolation of your streets,
Nor come we to add sorrow to your tears,
But to relieve them of their heavy load,
And these our Ships you happily may think,
Are like the Troian Horse, was stuffed within
With bloody veins expecting overthrow,
Are stored with Corn, to make your needy bread,
And give them life, whom hunger starved half dead.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: The Gods of Greece protect you
And we will pray for you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Arise I pray you, rise; we do not look for reverence,
But for love, and harborage for ourself, our ships, and men.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: The which when any shall not gratify,
Or pay you with unthankfulness in thought,
Be it our Wives, our Children, or ourselves,
The Curse of heaven and men succeed their evils:
Till when the which (I hope) shall near be seen:
Your Grace is welcome to our Town and us.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: Which welcome we will accept, feast here awhile,
Until our Stars that frown, lend us a smile.
Here have you seen a mighty King,
His child I'wis to incest bring:
A better Prince, and benign Lord,
That Will prove awful both in deed and word:
Be quiet then, as men should be,
Till he hath past necessity:
I will show you those in troubles reign;
Loosing a Mite, a Mountain gain:
The good in conversation,
To whom I give my benison:
Is still at Tharstill, where each man,
Thinks all is writ, he spoken can:
And to remember what he does,
Build his Statue to make him glorious:
But tidings to the contrary,
Are brought your eyes, what need speak I.
sp.stage: Enter at one dore Pericles talking with Cleon,all the traine with them: Enter at an other dore, a Gentleman with a Letter to Pericles, Pericles shewes the Letter to Cleon; Pericles giues the Messenger a reward, and Knights him: Exit Pericles at one dore, and Cleon at an other.
sp.l: Good Helicon that stayed at home,
Not to eat Honey like a Drone,
From others labours; for though he strive
To kill bad, keep good alive:
And to fulfil his prince desire,
Saved one of all that haps in Tyre:
How Thaliart came full bent with sin,
And hid in Tent to murdered him;
And that in Tharsis was not best,
Longer for him to make his rest:
He doing so, put forth to Seas;
Where when men been there is seldom ease,
For now the Wind begins to blow,
Thunder above, and deeps below,
Makes such unquiet, that the Ship,
Should house him safe; is wracked and split,
And he (good Prince) having all lost,
By Waves, from coast to coast is tossed:
All perish of man of pelf,
Ne aught escaped but himself;
Till Fortune tired with doing bad,
Threw him a shore, to give him glad:
And here he comes: what shall be next,
Pardon old Gower, this long is the text.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: Yet cease your ire you angry Stars of heaven,
Wind, Rain, and Thunder, remember earthly man
Is but a substance that must yield to you:
And I (as fits my nature) do obey you.
Alas, the Seas hath cast me on the Rocks,
Washed me from shore to shore, and left my breath
Nothing to think on, but ensuing death:
Let it suffice the greatness of your powers,
To have bereft a Prince of all his fortunes;
And having thrown him from your watery grave,
Here to have death in peace, is all he will crave.
What to pelch?
Ha, some and bring awat the Nets.
What Patch-breech, I say.
What say you Master?
Look how thou stirrest now:
Come away, or I will fetch thee with a wanion.
Faith Master, I am thinking of the poor men,
That were cast away before us even now.
Alas poor souls, it grieved my heart to hear,
What pitiful cries they made to us, to help them,
When (well-a-day) we could scarce help ourselves.
Nay Master, said not I as much,
When I saw the Porpoise how he bounced and tumbled?
They say they are half fish, half flesh:
A plague on them, they never come but I look to be washed.
Master, I marvel how the Fishes live in the Sea?
Why, as Men do a-land.
The great ones eat up the little ones:
I can compare our rich Misers to nothing so fitly,
As to a Whale; he plays and tumbles,
Driving the poor Fry before him,
And at last, devour them all at a mouthful:
Such Whales have I heard of, on the land,
Who never leave gaping, till they swallowed
The whole Parish, Church, Steeple, Bells and all.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: A pretty moral.
But Master, if I had been the Sexton,
I would have been that day in the belfry.
Why, Man?
Because he should have swallowed me too,
And when I had been in his belly,
I would have kept such a jangling of the Bells,
That he should never have left,
Till he cast Bells, Steeple, Church and Parish up again:
But if the good King Simonides were of my mind.
We would purge the land of these Drones,
That rob the Bee of her Honey.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: How from the finny subject of the Sea,
These Fishers tell the infirmities of men,
And from their watery empire recollect.
All that may men approve, or men detect.
Peace be at your labour, honest Fisher-men.
Honest good fellow what is that, if it be a day fits you
Search out of the Calendar, and nobody look after it?

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: May see the Sea hath cast upon your coast:
To cast thee in our way?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A man whom both the Waters and the Wind,
In that vast Tennis-court, hath made the Ball
For them to play upon, entreats you pity him:
He asks of you, that never used to beg.
Here is them in our country of Greece,
Gets more with begging, than we can do with working.
Canst thou catch any Fishes then?

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: I never practiced it.
Nay then thou wilt starve sure: for here is nothing to
be got nowadays, unless thou canst fish for it.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What I have been, I have forgot to know;
But what I am, want teaches me to think on:
A man thronged up with cold, my Veins are chill,
And have no more of life than may suffice,
To give my tongue that heat to ask your help:
Which if you shall refuse, when I am dead,
For that I am a man, pray you see me buried.

sp.p:
Die, quoth he; now God forbid it, and I have a Gown
here, come put it on, keep thee warm: now afore me a
handsome fellow: Come, thou shalt go home, and we will
have Flesh for all day, Fish for fasting-days and more; or
Puddings and Flap-jacks, and thou shalt be welcome.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I thank you sir.
Hark you my friend: You said you could not beg?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I did but crave.
But crave?
Then I will turn Craver too, and so I shall scape whipping.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why, are you Beggars whipped then?
O not all, my friend, not all: for if all your Beggars
were whipped, I would wish no better office, than to be Beadle:
But Master, I will go draw up the Net.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: How well this honest mirth becomes their labour?
Hark you sir; do you know where ye are?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Not well.
Why I will tell you, this I called Pantapoles,
And our King, the good Symonides.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: The good Symonides, do you call him?
Aye sir, and he deserves so to be called,
For his peaceable reign, and good government.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: He is a happy King, since he gains from
His subjects the name of good, by his government.
How far is his Court distant from this shore?
Marry sir, half a days journey: And I will tell you,
He hath a fair Daughter, and tomorrow is her birth-day,
And there are Princes and Knights come from all parts of
the World, to Just and Tourney for her love.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Were my fortunes equal to my desires,
I could wish to make one there.

sp.p: O Sir, things must be as they may: and what a man cannot get, he may lawfully deal for his Wives soul.

div1.stage: Enter the two Fisher-men, drawing up a Net.

sp.l: Help Master help; here is a Fish hangs in the Net,
Like a poor man's right in the law: it will hardly come out.
Ha bots on it, it is come at last; and it is turned to a rusty Armour.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: An Armour friends; I pray you let me see it.
Thanks Fortune, yet that after all crosses,
Thou givest me somewhat to repair myself:
And though it was mine own part of my heritage,
Which my dead Father did bequeath to me,
With this strict charge even as he left his life,
Keep it my Perycles, it hath been a Shield
Twixt me and death, and pointed to this brace,
For that it saved me, keep it in like necessity:
The which the Gods protect thee, Fame may defend thee:
It kept where I kept, I so dearly loved it,
Till the rough Seas, that spares not any man,
Took it in rage, though calmed, have given it again:
I thank thee for it, my shipwreck now is no ill,
Since I have here my Father gave in his Will.
What mean you sir?

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: To beg of you (kind friends) this Coat of worth,
For it was sometime Target to a King;
I know it by this mark: he loved me dearly,
And for his sake, I wish the having of it;
And that you would guide me to your Sovereigns Court,
Where with it, I may appear a Gentleman:
And if that ever my low fortune is better,
I will pay your bounties; till then, rest your debtor.
Why wilt thou tourney for the Lady?

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: I will show the virtue I have borne in Arms.
Why do ye take it: and the Gods give thee good in it.

sp.p:
Aye but hark you my friend, it was we that made up
this Garment through the rough seams of the Waters:
there are certain Condolements, certain Veils: I hope
sir, if you thrive, you will remember from whence you had
them.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: Believe it, I will:
By your furtherance I am clothed in Steel,
And spite of all the rupture of the Sea,
This Jewel holds his building on my arm:
Unto thy value I will mount myself
Upon a Courser, whose delight steps,
Shall make the gazer joy to see him tread;
Only (my friend) I yet am unprovided of a pair of Bases.
We will sure provide, thou shalt have
My best Gown to make thee a pair;
And I will bring thee to the Court myself.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: Then Honour be but a Goal to my Will,
This day I will rise, or else add ill to ill.

div1.stage: Enter Simonydes, with attendaunce, and Thaise.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Are the Knights ready to begin the Triumph?

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: They are my Liege, and stay your coming,
To present themselves.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Return them, We are ready, and our daughter here,
In honour of whose Birth, these Triumphs are,
Sits here like Beauties child, whom Nature begat,
For men to see; and seeing, wonder at.

sp.speaker: Thai.
sp.l: It pleaseth you (my royal Father) to express
My Commendations great, whose merit is less.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It is fit it should be so, for Princes are
A model which Heaven makes like to itself:
As Jewels lose their glory, if neglected,
So Princes their Renowns, if not respected:
It is now your honour (Daughter) to entertain
The labour of each Knight, in his device.

sp.speaker: Thai.
sp.l: Which to preserve mine honour, I will perform.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Who is the first, that doth prefer himself?

sp.speaker: Thai.
sp.l: A Knight of Sparta (my renowned father)
And the device he bears upon his Shield,
Is a black Ethyope reaching at the Sun:
The word: Lux tua vita mihi.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He loves you well, that holds his life of you.
Who is the second, that presents himself?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: A Prince of Macedon (my royal father)
And the device he bears upon his Shield,
Is an Armed Knight, that is conquered by a Lady:
The motto thus in Spanish. Pue Per doleera kee per forsa.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: And with the third?

sp.speaker: Thai.
sp.l: The third, of Antioch; and his device,
A wreath of Chivalry: the word: Me Pompey prouexit apex.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What is the fourth.

sp.speaker: Thai.
sp.l: A burning Torch that is turned upside down;
The word: Qui me alit me extinguit.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Which shows that Beauty hath his power and will,
Which can as well inflame, as it can kill.

sp.speaker: Thai.
sp.l: The fifth, an Hand environed with Clouds,
Holding out Gold, that is by the Touch-stone tried:
The motto thus: Sic spectanda fides.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: And what is the sixth, and last; the which,
The knight himself with such a graceful courtesy delivered?

sp.speaker: Thai.
sp.l: He seems to be a Stranger: but his Present is
A withered Branch, that is only green at top,
The motto: In hac spe viuo.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: A pretty moral from the dejected state wherein he is,
He hopes by you, his fortunes yet may flourish.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: He had need mean better, than his outward show
Can any way speak in his just commend:
For by his rusty outside, he appears,
To have practised more the Whipstock, than the Lance.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: He well may be a Stranger, for he comes
To an honoured triumph, strangely furnished.

sp.speaker: 3. Lord.
sp.l: And on set purpose let his Armour rust
Until this day, to scour it in the dust.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Opinion is but a fool, that makes us scan
The outward habit, by the inward man.
But stay, the Knights are coming,
We will with-draw into the Gallery.

div1.stage:
Great shoutes, and all cry, the meane Knight.
Enter the King and Knights from Tilting.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Knights, to say you are welcome, were superfluous.
I place upon the volume of your deeds,
As in a Title page, your worth in arms,
Were more than you expect, or more than is fit,
Since every worth in show commends itself:
Prepare for mirth, for mirth becomes a Feast.
You are Princes, and my guests.

sp.speaker: Thai.
sp.l: But you my Knight and guest,
To whom this Wreath of victory I give,
And crown you King of this days happiness.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: It is more by Fortune (Lady) than my Merit.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Call it by what you will, the day is your,
And here (I hope) is none that envies it:
In framing an Artist, art hath thus decreed,
To make some good, but others to exceed,
And you are her laboured scholar: come Queen a the feast,
For (Daughter) so you are; here take your place:
Martial the rest, as they deserve their grace.

sp.speaker: Knights.
sp.l: We are honoured much by good Symonides.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your presence glads our days, honour we love,
For who hates honour, hates the Gods above.

sp.speaker: Marshal.
sp.l: Sir, yonder is your place.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: Some other is more fit.

sp.speaker: 1. Knight.
sp.l: Contend not sir, for we are Gentlemen,
Have neither in our hearts, nor outward eyes,
Envies the great, nor shall the low despise.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: You are right courteous Knights.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sit sir, sit.
By Ioue (I wonder) that is King of thoughts,
These Cates resist me, he not thought upon.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: By Iuno (that is Queen of marriage)
All Viands that I eat do seem unsavoury,
Wishing him my meat: sure he is a gallant Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: He is but a country Gentleman: has done no more
Than other Knights have done, has broken a Staff,
Or so; so let it pass.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: To me he seems like Diamond, to Glass.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: You Kings to me, like to my fathers picture,
Which tells in that glory once he was,
Had Princes sit like Stars about his Throne,
And he the Sun for them to reverence;
None that beheld him, but like lesser lights,
Did vail their Crowns to his supremacy;
Where now his son like a Glowworm in the night,
The which hath Fire in darkness, none in light:
Whereby I see that Time is the King of men,
He is both their Parent, and he is their Grave,
And gives them what he will, not what they crave.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What, are you merry, Knights?

sp.speaker: Knights.
sp.l: Who can be other, in this royal presence.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Here, with a Cup that is stirred unto the brim,
As do you love, fill to your Mistress lips,
We drink this health to you.

sp.speaker: Knights.
sp.l: We thank your Grace.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet pause awhile, yon Knight doth sit too melancholy,
As if the entertainment in our Court,
Had not a show might countervail his worth:
Note it not you, Thaisa.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: What is it to me, my father?

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: O attend my Daughter,
Princes in this, should live like Gods above,
Who freely give to every one that come to honour them:
And Princes not doing so, are like to Gnats,
Which make a sound, but killed, are wondered at:
Therefore to make his entrance more sweet,
Here, say we drink this standing bowl of wine to him.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Alas my Father, it befits not me,
Unto a stranger Knight to be so bold,
He may my proffer take for an offence,
Since men take women's gifts for impudence.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: How? do as I bid you, or you will move me else.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Now by the Gods, he could not please me better.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: And furthermore tell him, we desire to know of him
Of whence he is, his name, and Parentage?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: The King my father (sir) has drunk to you.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: I thank him.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Wishing it so much blood unto your life.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: I thank both him and you, and pledge him freely.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: And further, he desires to know of you,
Of whence you are, your name and parentage?

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: A Gentleman of Tyre, my name Pericles,
My education been in Arts and Arms:
Who looking for adventures in the world,
Was by the rough Seas reft of Ships and men,
And after shipwreck, driven upon this shore.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: He thanks your Grace; names himself Pericles,
A Gentleman of Tyre: who only by misfortune of the seas,
Bereft of Ships and Men, cast on this shore.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Now by the Gods, I pity his misfortune,
And will awake him from his melancholy.
Come Gentlemen, we sit too long on trifles,
And waste the time which looks for other revels:
Even in your Armours as you are addressed,
Will well become a Soldiers dance:
I will not have excuse with saying this,
Loud Music is too harsh for Ladies heads,
Since they love men in arms, as well as beds.
So, this was well asked, it was so well performed.
Come sir, here is a Lady that wants breathing too,
And I have heard, you Knights of Tyre,
Are excellent in making Ladies trip;
And that their Measures are as excellent.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: In those that practise them, they are (my Lord.)

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: O that is as much, as you would be denied
Of your fair courtesy: unclasp, unclasp.
Thanks Gentlemen to all, all have done well;
But you the best: Pages and lights, to conduct
These Knights unto their several Lodgings:
Yours sir, we have given order be next our own.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: I am at your Graces pleasure.
Princes, it is too late to talk of Love,
And that is the mark I know, you level at:
Therefore each one betake him to his rest,
Tomorrow all for speeding do their best:

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: No Escanes, know this of me,
Antiochus from incest lived not free:
For which the most high Gods not minding,
Longer to with-hold the vengeance that
They had in store, due to this heinous
Capital offence, even in the height and pride
Of all his glory, when he was seated in
A Chariot of an inestimable value, and his daughter
With him; a fire from heaven came and shrivelled
Up those bodies even to loathing, for they so stunk,
That all those eyes adored them, ere their fall,
Scorn now their hand should give them burial.

sp.speaker: Escanes.
sp.l: It was very strange.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: And yet but justice; for though this King were great,
His greatness was no guard to bar heavens shaft,
But sin had his reward.

sp.speaker: Escan.
sp.l: It is very true.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: See, not a man in private conference,
Or counsel, has respect with him but he.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: It shall no longer grieve, without reproof.

sp.speaker: 3. Lord.
sp.l: And cursed be he that will not second it.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: Follow me then: Lord Hellicane, a word.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: With me? and welcome happy day, my Lords.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: Know, that our griefs are risen to the top,
And now at length they oer-flow their banks.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Your griefs, for what?
Wrong not your Prince, you love.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: Wrong not yourself then, noble Hellican,
But if the Prince do live, let us salute him,
Or know what ground is made happy by his breath:
If in the world he live, we will seek him out:
If in his Grave he rest, we will find him there,
And be resolved he lives to govern us:
Or dead, give us cause to mourn his funeral,
And leave us to our free election.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: Whose death in deed, the strongest in our censure,
And knowing this Kingdom is without a head,
Like goodly Buildings left without a Roof,
Soon fall to ruin: your noble self,
That best know how to rule, and how to reign,
We thus submit unto our Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Live noble Hellicane.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Try honours cause; forbear your suffrages:
If that you love Prince Pericles, forbear,
(Take I your wish, I leap into the seas,
Where is hourly trouble, for a minutes ease)
A twelve-month longer, let me entreat you
To forbear the absence of your King;
If in which time expired, he not return,
I shall with aged patience bear your yoke:
But if I cannot win you to this love,
Go search like nobles, like noble subjects,
And in your search, spend your adventurous worth,
Whom if you find, and win unto return,
You shall like Diamonds sit about his Crown.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: To wisdom, he is a fool, that will not yield:
And since Lord Hellicane enjoineth us,
We with our travels will endeavour.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Then you love us, we you, and we will clasp hands:
When Peers thus knit, a Kingdom ever stands.

div1.stage: Enter the King reading of a letter at one doore, the Knightes meete him.

sp.speaker: 1. Knight.
sp.l: Good morrow to the good Simonides.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Knights, from my daughter this I let you know,
That for this twelve-month, she will not undertake
A married life: her reason to herself is only known,
Which from her, by no means can I get.

sp.speaker: 2. Knight.
sp.l: May we not get access to her (my Lord?)

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Faith, by no means, she hath so strictly
Tied her to her Chamber, that it is impossible:
One twelve Moons more she will wear Dianas livery:
This by the eye of Cinthya hath she vowed,
And on her Virgin honour, will not break it.

sp.speaker: 3. knight.
sp.l: Loath to bid farewell, we take our leaves.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: So, they are well dispatched:
Now to my daughters Letter; she tells me here,
She will wed the stranger Knight,
Or never more to view nor day nor light.
It is well Mistress, your choice agrees with mine:
I like that well: nay how absolute she is in it,
Not minding whether I dislike or no.
Well, I do commend her choice, and will no longer
Have it be delayed: Soft, here he comes,
I must dissemble it.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: All fortune to the good Symonides.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To you as much: Sir, I am beholding to you
For your sweet Music this last night:
I do protest, my ears were never better fed
With such delightful pleasing harmony.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: It is your Graces pleasure to commend,
Not my desert.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Sir, you are Musics master.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: The worst of all her scholars (my good Lord.)

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Let me ask you one thing:
What do you think of my Daughter, sir?

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: A most virtuous Princess.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: And she is fair too, is she not?

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: As a fair day in Summer: wondrous fair.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Sir, my Daughter thinks very well of you,
Aye so well, that you must be her Master,
And she will be your Scholar; therefore look to it.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: I am unworthy for her Schoolmaster.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: She thinks not so: peruse this writing else.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What is here, a letter that she loves the knight of Tyre.
It is the Kings subtlety to have my life:
O seek not to entrap me, gracious Lord,
A Stranger, and distressed Gentleman,
That never aimed so hie, to love your Daughter,
But bent all offices to honour her.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Thou hast bewitched my daughter,
And thou art a villain.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: By the Gods I have not; never did thought
Of mine levy offence; nor never did my actions
Yet commence a deed might gain her love,
Or your displeasure.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Traitor, thou liest.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: Traitor?

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Aye, traitor.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: Even in his throat, unless it be the King,
That calls me Traitor, I return the lie.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Now by the Gods, I do applaud his courage.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: My actions are as noble as my thoughts,
That never relished of a base descent:
I came unto your Court for Honours cause,
And not to be a Rebel to her state:
And he that otherwise accounts of me,
This Sword shall prove, he is Honours enemy.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: No? here comes my Daughter, she can witness it.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: Then as you are as virtuous, as fair,
Resolve your angry Father, if my tongue
Did ever solicit, or my hand subscribe
To any syllable that made love to you?

sp.speaker: Thai.
sp.l: Why sir, say if you had, who takes offence?
At that, would make me glad?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yea Mistress, are you so peremptory?
I am glad of it with all my heart,
I will tame you; I will bring you in subjection.
Will you not, having my consent,
Bestow your love and your affections,
Upon a Stranger? who for aught I know,
May be (nor can I think the contrary)
As great in blood as I myself:
Therefore, hear you Mistress, either frame
Your will to mine: and you sir, hear you;
Either be ruled by me, or I will make you,
Man and wife: nay come, your hands,
And lips must seal it too: and being joined,
I will thus your hopes destroy, and for further grief:
God give you joy; what are you both pleased?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.l: Yes, if you love me sir?

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: Even as my life, my blood that fosters it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What are you both agreed?

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: Yes, if it please your Majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It pleaseth me so well, that I will see you wed,
And then with what haste you can, get you to bed.
Now sleep slaked hath the rout,
No din but snores about the house,
Made louder by the overfed breast,
Of this most pompous marriage Feast:
The Cat with eyes of burning cole,
Now couches from the Mouses hole;
And Cricket sing at the Ovens mouth,
Are the blither for their drought:
Hymen hath brought the Bride to bed,
Whereby the loss of maidenhead,
A Babe is moulded: be attent,
And Time that is so briefly spent,
With your fine fancies quaintly each,
What is dumb in show, I will plain with speech.
sp.stage: Enter Pericles and Symonides at one dore with attendantes, a Messenger meetes them, kneeles and giues Pericles a letter, Pericles shewes it Symonides, the Lords kneele to him; then enter Thaysa with child, with Lichorida a nurse, the King shewes her the letter, she reioyces>: she and Pericles take leaue of her father, and depart.
sp.l: By many a dern and painful perch
Of Perycles the careful search,
By the four opposing Crignes,
Which the world together joins,
Is made with all due diligence,
That horse and sail and hie expense,
Can steed the quest at last from Tyre:
Fame answering the most strange enquire,
To the Court of King Symonides,
Are Letters brought, the tenor these:
Antiochus and his daughter dead,
The men of Tyrus, on the head
Of Helycanus would set on
The Crown of Tyre, but he will none:
The mutiny, he there hastes to oppress,
Says to them, if King Pericles
Come not home in twice six Moons,
He obedient to their dooms,
Will take the Crown: the sum of this,
Brought hither to Pentapolis,
ravished the regions round,
And every one with claps can sound,
Our heir apparent is a King:
Who dreamt? who thought of such a thing?
Brief he must hence depart to Tyre,
His Queen with child, makes her desire,
Which who shall cross along to go,
Omit we all their dole and woe:
Lichorida her Nurse she takes,
And so to Sea; their vessel shakes,
On Neptunes billow, half the flood,
Hath their Keel cut: but fortune moved,
Varies again, the grizzled North
Disgorges such a tempest forth,
That as a Duck for life that dives,
So up and down the poor Ship drives:
The Lady shrieks, and well-a-near,
Does fall in travail with her fear:
And what ensues in this fell storm,
Shall for itself, itself perform:
I shall not relate, action may
Conveniently the rest convey;
Which might not? what by me is told,
In your imagination hold:
This Stage, the Ship, upon whose Deck
The seas tossed Pericles appears to speak.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: The God of this great Vast, rebuke these surges,
Which wash both heaven and hell, and thou that hast
Upon the Winds command, bind them in Brass;
Having called them from the deep, O still
Thy deafening dreadful thunders, gently quench
Thy nimble sulphurous flashes: O How Lychorida!
How does my Queen? then storm venomously,
Wilt thou spate all thyself? the sea-man's Whistle
Is as a whisper in the ears of death,
Divinest patroness, and my wife gentle
To those that cry by night, convey thy deity
Aboard our dancing Boat, make swift the pangs
Of my Queens travails? now Lychorida.

sp.speaker: Lychor.
sp.l: Here is a thing too young for such a place,
Who if it had conceit, would die, as I am like to do:
Take in your arms this piece of your dead Queen.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: How? how Lychorida?

sp.speaker: Lycho.
sp.l: Patience (good sir) do not assist the storm,
Here is all that is left living of your Queen;
A little Daughter: for the sake of it,
Be manly, and take comfort.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: O you Gods!
Why do you make us love your goodly gifts,
And snatch them straight away? we here below,
Recall not what we give, and therein may
Use honour with you.

sp.speaker: Lycho.
sp.l: Patience (good sir) even for this charge.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Now mild may be thy life,
For a more blusterous birth had never Babe:
Quiet and gentle thy conditions; for
Thou art the rudliest welcome to this world,
That ever was Princes Child: happy what follows,
Thou hast as chiding a nativity,
As Fire, Air, Water, Earth, and Heaven can make,
To herald thee from the womb:
Even at the first, thy loss is more than can
Thy portage quit, with all thou canst find here:
Now the good Gods throw their best eyes upon it.

sp.speaker: 1. Sayl.
sp.l: What courage sir? God save you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Courage enough, I do not fear the flaw,
It hath done to me the worst: yet for the love
Of this poor Infant, this fresh new seafarer,
I would it would be quiet.

sp.speaker: 1. Sayl.
sp.p:
Slake the bolins there; thou wilt not wilt thou?
Blow and split thyself.

sp.speaker: 2. Sayl.
sp.l: But Sea-room, and the brine and cloudy billow
Kiss the Moon, I care not.
Sir your Queen must over board, the sea works hie,
The Wind is loud, and will not lie till the Ship
Be cleared of the dead.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: That is your superstition.
Pardon us, Sir; with us at Sea it hath been still observed.
And we are strong in eastern, therefore briefly yield her,

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: As you think meet; for she must over board straight:
Most wretched Queen

sp.speaker: Lychor.
sp.l: Here she lies sir.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: A terrible Child-bed hast thou had (my dear,
No light, no fire, the unfriendly elements,
Forgot thee utterly, nor have I time
To give thee hallowed to thy grave, but straight,
Must cast thee scarcely Coffined, in oar,
Where for a monument upon thy bones,
The air remaining lamps, the belching Whale,
And humming Water must overwhelm thy corpse,
Lying with simple shells: O Lychorida,
Bid Nestor bring me Spices, Ink, and Taper,
My Casket, and my Jewels; and bid Nicander
Bring me the Satin Coffin: lay the Babe
Upon the Pillow; hie thee whiles I say
A priestly farewell to her: suddenly, woman.
Sir, we have a Chest beneath the hatches,
Caulked and bitumed ready.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: I thank thee: Mariner say, what Coast is this?
We are near Tharsus.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: Thither gentle Mariner,
Alter thy course for Tyre: When canst thou reach it?
By break of day, if the Wind cease.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: O make for Tharsus,
There will I visit Cleon, for the Babe
Cannot hold out to Tyrus; there I will leave it
At careful nursing: go thy ways good Mariner,
I will bring the body presently.

div1.stage: Enter Lord Cerymon with a seruant.

sp.speaker: Cery.
sp.l: Phylemon, ho.

sp.speaker: Phyl
sp.l: Doth my Lord call?

sp.speaker: Cery.
sp.l: Get Fire and meat for these poor men,
It has been a turbulent and stormy night.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: I have been in many; but such a night as this,
Till now, I never endured:

sp.speaker: Cery.
sp.l: Your Master will be dead ere you return,
There is nothing can be ministered to Nature,
That can recover him: give this to the Apothecary,
And tell me how it works.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Good morrow.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Good morrow to your Lordship,

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Sir, our lodgings standing bleak upon the sea,
Shook as the earth did quake:
The very principals did seem to rend and all to topple:
Pure surprise and fear, made me to quite the house.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: That is the cause we trouble you so early,
It is not our husbandry.

sp.speaker: Cery.
sp.l: O you say well.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: But I much marvel that your Lordship,
Having rich tire about you, should at these early hours,
Shake off the golden slumber of repose; it is most strange
Nature should be so conversant with Pain,
Being thereto not compelled.

sp.speaker: Cery.
sp.l: I hold it ever Virtue and Cunning,
Were endowments greater, than Nobleness and Riches;
Careless Heirs, may the two latter darken and expend;
But Immortality attends the former,
Making a man a god:
It is known, I ever haue studied Physic:
Through which secret Art, by turning over Authorities,
I have together with my practise, made familiar,
To me and to my aid, the blessed infusions that dwells
In Vegetives, in Metals, Stones: and can speak of the
Disturbances that Nature works, and of her cures;
Which doth give me a more content in course of true delight
Than to be thirsty after tottering honour, or
Tie my pleasure up in silken Bags,
To please the Fool and Death.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Your honour has through Ephesus,
Poured forth your charity, and hundreds call themselves,
Your Creatures; who by you, have been restored;
And not your knowledge, your personal pain,
But even your Purse still open, hath built Lord Cerimon,
Such strong renown, as time shall never.

div1.stage: Enter two or three with a Chist.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: So, lift there.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir, even now did the sea toss up upon our shore
This Chest; it is of some wrack.

l.reg: Set it down, let us look upon it.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: It is like a Coffin, sir.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.l: Whatever it be, it is wondrous heavy;
Wrench it open straight:
If the Seas stomach be overcharged with Gold,
It is a good constraint of Fortune it belches upon us.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: It is so, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.l: How close it is caulked and bottomed, did the sea cast it up?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I never saw so huge a billow sir, as tossed it upon shore.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.l: Wrench it open soft; it smells most sweetly in my sense.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A delicate Odour.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.l: As ever hit my nostril: so, up with it.
O you most potent Gods! what is here, a Corse?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Most strange.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.p:
Shrouded in Cloth of state, balmed and entreasured
with full bags of Spices, a Passport to Apollo,
perfect me
in the Characters:

sp.l: Here I give to understand,
If ever this Coffin drives aland;
I King Pericles have lost
This Queen, worth all our mundane cost:
Who finds her, give her burying,
She was the Daughter of a King:
Besides, this Treasure for a fee,
The Gods requite his charity.
If thou livest Pericles, thou hast a heart,
That ever cracks for woe, this chanced tonight.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Most likely sir.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.l: Nay certainly tonight, for look how fresh she looks
They were too rough, that threw her in the sea.
Make a Fire within; fetch hither all my Boxes in my Closet,
Death may usurp on Nature many hours, and yet
The fire of life kindle again the over-pressed spirits:
I heard of an Egyptian that had nine hours lain dead,
Who was by good appliance recovered.
sp.stage: Enter one with Napkins and Fire.
sp.l: Well said, well said; the fire and clothes: the rough and
Woeful Music that we have, cause it to sound beseech you:
The Viol once more; how thou stirrest thou block?
The Music there: I pray you give her air:
Gentlemen, this Queen will live,
Nature awakes a warmth breath out of her;
She hath not been entranced above five hours:
See how she begins to blow into life's flower again.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: The Heavens, through you, increase our wonder,
And sets up your fame for ever.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.l: She is alive, behold her eyelids,
Cases to those heavenly jewels which Pericles hath lost,
Begin to part their fringes of bright gold,
The Diamonds of a most praised water doth appear,
To make the world twice rich, live, and make us weep.
To hear your fate, fair creature, rare as you seem to be.

sp.speaker: Thai.
sp.l: O dear Diana, where am I? where is my Lord?
What world is this?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Is not this strange?

sp.speaker: 1.Gent.
sp.l: Most rare.

sp.speaker: Ceri.
sp.l: Hush (my gentle neighbours) lend me your hands,
To the next Chamber bear her: get linen:
Now this matter must be looked to for her relapse
Is mortal: come, come; and Escelapius guide us.

div1.stage: They carry her away. Exeunt omnes. Enter Pericles, Atharsus, with Cleon and Dionisa.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Most honoured Cleon, I must needs be gone, my twelve
months are expired, and Tyrus stands in a litigious peace:
You and your Lady take from my heart all thankfulness,
The Gods make up the rest upon you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Your shakes of fortune, though they haunt you mortally
Yet glance full wonderingly on us.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.p:
O your sweet Queen! that the strict fates had pleased,
you had brought her hither to have blessed mine eyes with her.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: We cannot but obey the powers above us;
Could I rage and roar as doth the sea she lies in,
Yet the end must be as it is: my gentle babe Marina,
Whom, for she was born at sea, I have named so,
Here I charge your charity withal; leaving her
The infant of your care, beseeching you to give her
Princely training, that she may be mannered as she is born.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Fear not (my Lord) but think your Grace,
That fed my Country with your Corn; for which,
The peoples prayers still fall upon you, must in your child
Be thought on, if negligence should therein make me vile,
The common body by you relieved,
Would force me to my duty: but if to that,
My nature need a spur, the Gods revenge it
Upon me and mine, to the end of generation.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I believe you, your honour and your goodness,
Teach me to it without your vows, till she be married,
Madam, by bright Diana, whom we honour,
All unsisterd shall this heir of mine remain,
Though I show will in it; so I take my leave:
Good Madam, make me blessed in your care
In bringing up my Child.

sp.speaker: Dion.
sp.p:
I have one myself, who shall not be more dear
to my respect than yours, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.l: Madam, my thanks and prayers.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p:
We will bring your Grace even to the edge of the shore,
then give you up to the masked Neptune, and the gentlest
winds of heaven.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.p:
I will embrace your offer, come dearest Madam,
O no tears Licherida, no tears, look to your little Mistress,
on whose grace you may depend hereafter: come my
Lord.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.l: Madam, this Letter, and some certain Jewels,
Lay with you in your Coffer, which are at your command:
Know you the Character?

sp.speaker: Thar.
sp.p:
It is my Lords, that I was shipped at sea I well remember,
even on my learning time, but whether there delivered,
by the holy gods I cannot rightly say: but since King
Pericles my wedded Lord, I never shall see again, a vestal
livery will I take me to, and never more have joy.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Madam, if this you purpose as ye speak,
Dianaes Temple is not distant far,
Where you may abide till your date expire,
Moreover if you please a Niece of mine,
Shall there attend you.

sp.speaker: Thin.
sp.l: My recompense is thanks, that is all,
Yet my good will is great, though the gift small.
Imagine Pericles arrived at Tyre,
Welcomed and settled to his own desire:
His woeful Queen we leave at Ephesus,
Unto Diana there is a Votaress.
Now to Marina bend your mind,
Whom our fast growing scene must find
At Tharsus, and by Cleon trained
In Musics letters, who hath gained
Of education all the grace,
Which makes hie both the art and place
Of general wonder: but alack
That monster Envy oft the wrack
Of earned praise, Marinas life
Seek to take off by treasons knife,
And in this kind, our Cleon hath
One daughter and a full grown wench,
Even right for marriage light: this Maid
Hight Philoten: and it is said
For certain in our story, she
Would ever with Marina be.
Be it when they wove the sledded silk,
With fingers long, small, white as milk,
Or when she would with sharpe needle wound,
The Cambric which she made more sound
By hurting it or when to the Lute
She sung, and made the night bed mute,
That still records with moan, or when
She would with rich and constant pen,
Vail to her Mistress Dian still,
This Phyloten contends in skill
With absolute Marina: so
The Dove of Paphos might with the crow
Vie feathers white, Marina gets
All praises, which are paid as debts,
And not as given, this so darks
In Phyloten all graceful marks,
That Cleons wife with Envy rare,
A present murderer does prepare
For good Marina, that her daughter
Might stand peerless by this slaughter.
The sooner her vile thoughts to stead,
Lichorida our nurse is dead,
And cursed Dioniza hath
The pregnant instrument of wrath.
Pressed for this blow, the unborn event,
I do commend to your content,
Only I carried winged Time,
Post one the lame feet of my rime,
Which never could I so convey,
Unless your thoughts went on my way,
Dioniza does appear,
With Leonine a murtherer.

sp.speaker: Dion.
sp.p:
Thy oath remember, thou hast sworn to do it,
it is but a blow which never shall be known, thou
canst not do a thing in the world so soon to yield
thee so much profit: let not conscience which is but
cold, in flaming, thy love bosom, inflame too nicely,
nor let pity which even women have cast off, melt thee,
but be a soldier to thy purpose.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I will do it, but yet she is a goodly creature.

sp.speaker: Dion.
sp.l: The fitter then the Gods should have her.
Here she comes weeping for her only Mistress death,
Thou art resolved.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I am resolved.

div1.stage: Enter Marina with a Basket of flowers.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p:
No: I will rob Tellus of her weed to strew
thy green with Flowers, the yellows, blues, the purple
Violets, and Marigolds, shall as a Carpet hang upon thy
grave, while Summer days doth last: Aye me poor maid,
born in a tempest, when my mother died, this world to me
is a lasting storm, whirring me from my friends.

sp.speaker: Dion.
sp.l: How now Marina, why do you keep alone?
How chance my daughter is not with you?
Do not consume your blood with sorrowing,
Have you a nurse of me? Lord how your favours
Changed with this unprofitable woe:
Come give me your flowers, ere the sea mar it,
Walk with Leonine, the air is quick there,
And it pierces and sharpens the stomach,
Come Leonine take her by the arm, walk with her.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: No pray you, I will not bereave you of your servant.

sp.speaker: Dion.
sp.p:
Come, come, I love the king your father, and yourself,
with more then foreign heart, we every day expect
him here, when he shall come and find our Paragon to all
reports thus blasted,
He will repent the breadth of his great voyage, blame both
my Lord and me, that we have taken no care to your best
courses, go I pray you, walk and be cheerful once again,
reserve that excellent complexion, which did steal the
eyes of young and old. Care not for me, I can go home alone.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Well, I will go, but yet I have no desire to it.

sp.speaker: Dion.
sp.p:
Come, come, I know it is good for you, walk half
an hour Leonine, at the least, remember what I have said.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I warrant you Madam.

sp.speaker: Dion.
sp.p:
I will leave you my sweet Lady, for a while, pray
walk softly, do not heat your blood, what, I must have
care of you.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p:
My thanks sweet Madam, Is this wind Westerly
that blows?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Southwest.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: When I was born the wind was North.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Was it so?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p:
My father, as nurse says, did never fear, but cried
good sea-men to the Sailors, galling his kingly hands haling
ropes, and clasping to the Mast, endured a sea that almost
burst the deck.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: When was this?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p:
When I was born, never was waves nor wind
more violent, and from the ladder tackle, washes off a canvas
climber, ha says one, wolt out? and with a dropping industry
they skip from stern to stern, the Boatswain
whistles, and the Master calls and trebles their confusion.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Come say your prayers.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
If you require a little space for prayer, I grant it,
pray, but be not tedious, for the Gods are quick of ear,
and I am sworn to do my work with haste.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Why will you kill me?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: To satisfy my Lady.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p:
Why would she have me killed now? as I can remember
by my troth, I never did her hurt in all my life, I
never spake bad word, nor did ill turn to any living creature:
Believe me law, I never killed a Mouse, nor hurt a Fly:
I trod upon a worm against my will, but I wept for it. How
have I offended, wherein my death might yield her any
profit, or my life imply her any danger?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
My Commission is not to reason of the deed, but
do it.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p:
You will not do it for all the world I hope: you
are well favoured, and your looks foreshow you have a
gentle heart, I saw you lately when you caught hurt in parting
two that fought: good sooth it showed well in you, do
so now, your Lady seeks my life Come, you between, and
save poor me the weaker.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I am sworn and will dispatch.

sp.speaker: 1. Pirat.
sp.l: Hold villain.

sp.speaker: 2. Pira.
sp.l: A prize, a prize.

sp.speaker: 3. Pirat.
sp.p:
Half part mates, half part. Come let us have
her aboard suddenly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
These roguing thieves serve the great Pirate
Valdes, and they have seized Marina, let her go, there is no
hope she will return, I will swear she is dead, and thrown
into the Sea, but I will see further: perhaps they will but
please themselves upon her, not carry her aboard, if she
remain
Whom they have ravished, must by me be slain.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Pander.
sp.p:
Search the market narrowly, Mettelyne is
full of gallants, we lost too much much money this mart
by being too wenchless.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
We were never so much out of Creatures, we
have but poor three, and they can do no more than they
can do, and they with continual action, are even as good
as rotten.

sp.speaker: Pander.
sp.p:
Therefore let us have fresh ones whatever we pay
for them, if there be not a conscience to be used in every
trade, we shall never prosper.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
Thou sayst true, it is not our bringing up of poor
bastards, as I think, I have brought up some eleven.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
aye to eleven, and brought them down again,
but shall I search the market?

sp.speaker: Bawde.
sp.p:
What else man? the stuff we have, a strong
wind will blow it to pieces, they are so pitifully sodden.

sp.speaker: Pander.
sp.p:
Thou sayst true, there is too unwholesome a
conscience, the poor Transiluanian is dead that lay with
the little baggage.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
Aye, she quickly pooped him, she made him roast-meat
for worms, but I will go search the market.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
Three or four thousand Chequins were as
pretty a proportion to live quietly, and so give over.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
Why, to give over I pray you? Is it a shame to
get when we are old?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
O our credit comes not in like the commodity,
nor the commodity wages not with the danger:
therefore if in our youths we could pick up some pretty
estate, it were not amiss to keep our door hatched, besides
the sore terms we stand upon with the gods, will be strong
with us for giving over.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Come other sorts offend as well as we.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
As well as we, Aye, and better too, we offend
worse, neither is our profession any trade, It is no calling,
but here comes Boult.

div1.stage: Enter Boult with the Pirates and Marina.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
Come your ways my masters, you say she is a
virgin.

sp.speaker: Sayler.
sp.l: O Sir, we doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
Master, I have gone through for this piece you
see, if you like her so, if not I have lost my earnest.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Boult, has she any qualities?

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
She has a good face, speaks well, and has excellent
good clothes: there is no farther necessity of qualities
can make her be refused.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: What is her price Boult?

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.l: I cannot be bated one doit of a thousand pieces.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
Well, follow me my masters, you shall have your
money presently, wife take her in, instruct her what she has
to do, that she may not be raw in her entertainment.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
Boult, take you the marks of her, the colour of
her hair, complexion, height, her age, with warrant of her
virginity, and cry; He that will give most shall have her first,
such a maidenhead were no cheap thing, if men were as
they have been: get this done as I command you.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.l: Performance shall follow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Alack that Leonine was so slack, so slow, he should
have struck, not spoke, or that these Pirates, not enough
barbarous, had not overboard thrown me, for to seek my
mother.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Why lament you pretty one?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That I am pretty.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Come, the Gods have done their part in you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I accuse them not.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
You are light into my hands, where you are like
to live.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
The more my fault, to scape his hands, where I
was to die.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Aye, and you shall live in pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
Yes indeed shall you, and taste Gentlemen of all
fashions, you shall fare well, you shall have the difference of
all complexions, what do you stop your ears?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Are you a woman?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
What would you have me be, and I
be not a
woman?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: An honest woman, or not a woman.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
Marie whip the Gosling, I think I shall have
something to do with you, come you are a young foolish
sapling, and must be bowed as I would have you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The Gods defend me.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p:
If it please the Gods to defend you by men, then
men must comfort you, men must feed you, men stir you
up Boults returned. Now sir, hast thou cried her through
the Market?

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
I have cried her almost to the number of her
hairs, I have drawn her picture with my voice.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p:
And I prithee tell me, how dost thou find the inclination
of the people, especially of the younger sort?

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
Faith they listened to me, as they would have
hearkened to their fathers testament, there was a Spaniards
mouth watered, and he went to bed to her very description.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p:
We shall have him here tomorrow with his best
ruff on.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
Tonight, tonight, but Mistress do you know
the French knight, that cowers in the hams?

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.l: Who, Monsieur Verollus?

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
Aye, he, he offered to cut a caper at the proclamation,
but he made a groan at it, and swore he would see her
tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p:
Well, well, as for him, he brought his disease hither,
here he does but repair it, I know he will come in
our shadow, to scatter his crowns in the Sun.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
Well, if we had of every Nation a traveller, we
should lodge them with this sign.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p:
Pray you come hither a while, you have
Fortunes coming upon you, mark me, you must
seem to do that fearfully, which you commit willingly,
despise profit, where you have most gain, to weep
that you live as ye do, makes pity in your Lovers seldom,
but that pity begets you a good opinion, and that
opinion a mere profit.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
O take her home Mistress, take her home, these
blushes of hers must be quenched with some present
practise.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p:
Thou sayst true in faith, so they must, for your
Bride goes to that with shame, which is her way to go with
warrant.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
Faith some do, and some do not, but Mistress
if I have bargained for the joint.

sp.speaker: Band.
sp.l: Thou mayst cut a morsel off the spit.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.l: I may so.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p:
Who should deny it?
Come young one, I like the manner of your garments
well.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.l: Aye by my faith, they shall not be changed yet.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p:
Boult, spend thou that in the town: report what
a sojourner we have, you will lose nothing by custom.
When Nature framed this piece, she meant thee a good
turn, therefore say what a paragon she is, and thou hast
the harvest out of thine own report.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
I warrant you Mistress, thunder shall not so awake
wake the beds of Eels, as my giving out her beauty stirs
up the lewdly inclined, I will bring home some tonight.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.l: Come your ways, follow me.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: If fires be hot, knives sharpe, or waters deep,
Untied I still my virgin knot will keep.
Diana aid my purpose.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p:
What have we to do with Diana, pray you will
you go with us?

sp.speaker: Dion.
sp.l: Why ere you foolish, can it be undone?

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: O Dioniza, such a piece of slaughter,
The Sun and Moon never looked upon.

sp.speaker: Dion.
sp.l: I think you will turn a child again.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.p:
Were I chief Lord of all this spacious world, I would
give it to undo the deed. O Lady much less in blood than
virtue, yet a Princes to equal any single Crown on the earth
in the Justice of compare, O villain, Leonine whom thou hast
poisoned too, if thou hadst drunk to him it had been a
kindness becoming well thy face, what canst thou say
when noble Pericles shall demand his child?

sp.speaker: Dion.
sp.p:
That she is dead. Nurses are not the fates to foster
it, not ever to preserve, she died at night, I will say so, who
can cross it unless you play the impious Innocent, and
for an honest attribute, cry out she died by foul
play.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
O go to, well, well, of all the faults beneath the
heavens, the Gods do like this worst.

sp.speaker: Dion.
sp.p:
Be one of those that thinks the petty wrens of
Tharsus will fly hence, and open this to Pericles, I do shame
to think of what a noble strain you are, and of how coward
a spirit.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
To such proceeding who ever but his approbation
added, though not his prince consent, he did not flow
from honourable courses.

sp.speaker: Dion.
sp.p:
Be it so then, yet none does know but you
how she came dead, nor none can know Leonine being
gone. She did disdain my child, and stood between
her and her fortunes: none would look on her, but
cast their gazes on Marianas face, whilst ours was blurted
at, and held a Malkin not worth the time of day.
It pierced me through, and though you call my course unnatural,
you not your child well loving, yet I find it
greets me as an enterprise of kindness performed to your
sole daughter.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Heavens forgive it.

sp.speaker: Dion.
sp.p:
And as for Pericles, what should he say, we wept
after her hearse, and yet we mourn, her monument is almost
finished, and her epitaphs in glittering golden characters express
a general praise to her, and care in us at whose expense
it is done.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Thou art like the Harpy,
Which to betray, dost with thine Angels face seize with
thine Eagles talents.

sp.speaker: Dion.
sp.p:
You are like one that superstitiously,
Do swear to the Gods, that Winter kills
The Flies, but yet I know, you will
do as I advise.

div1.stage: Exeunt. Before Marina's monument at Tharsus. Enter Gower.

sp.speaker: Gower.
sp.l: Thus time we waste, and long leagues make short,
Sail seas in Cockles, have and wish but for it,
Making to take our imagination,
From bourne to bourne, region to region,
By you being pardoned we commit no crime,
To use one language, in each several clime,
