Where our scenes seems to live,
I do beseech you
To learn of me who stand with gaps
To teach you.
The stages of our story Pericles
Is now again thwarting thy wayward seas,
Attended on by many a Lord and Knight,
To see his daughter all his lives delight.
Old Helicanus goes along behind,
Is left to govern it, you bear in mind.
Old Escenes, whom Hellicanus late
Advanced in time to great and hie estate.
Well sailing ships, and bounteous winds
Have brought
This king to Tharsus, think this Pilot thought
So with his steerage, shall your thoughts groan
To fetch his daughter home, who first is gone
Like moats and shadows, see them
Move a while,
Your ears unto your eyes I will reconcile.

div1.stage: Enter Pericles at one doore, with all his trayne, Cleon and Dioniza at the other. Cleon shewes Pericles the tombe, whereat Pericles makes lamentation, puts on sacke-cloth, and in a mighty passion departs.

sp.speaker: Gowr.
sp.l: See how belief may suffer by foul show,
This borrowed passion stands for true old woe:
And Pericles in sorrow all devoured,
With sighs shot through, and biggest tears overshowered.
Leaves Tharsus, and again embarks, he swears
never to wash his face, nor cut his hairs:
He put on sack-cloth, and to Sea he bears,
A Tempest which his mortal vessel tears.
And yet he rides it out, Now please you wit:
The Epitaph is for Marina writ, by wicked Dioniza.
The fairest, sweetest, and best lies here,
Who withered in her spring of year:
She was of Tyrus the Kings daughter,
On whom foul death hath made this slaughter.
Marina was she called, and at her birth
Thetis being proud, swallowed some part of the earth:
Therefore the earth fearing to be overflowed.
Hath Thetis birth-child on the heavens bestowed.
Wherefore she does and swears she will never stint,
Make raging Battery upon shores of flint.
No visor does become black villainy,
So well as soft and tender flattery:
Let Pericles believe his daughter is dead,
And bear his courses to be ordered;
By Lady Fortune, while our Steer must play,
His daughters woe and heavy well-a-day.
In her unholy service: Patience then,
And think you now are all in Mittelin.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Did you ever hear the like?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p:
No, nor never shall do in such a place as this,
she being once gone.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p:
But to have divinity preached there, did you ever
dream of such a thing?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p:
No, no, come, I am for no more bawdy houses, shall us
go hear the Vestals sing?

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p:
I will do anything now that is virtuous, but I am out
of the road of rutting for ever.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
Well, I had rather than twice the worth of her
she had never come here.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
Fie, fie, upon her, she is able to freeze the god
Priapus, undo a whole generation, we must either get
her ravished, or be rid of her, when she should do for Clients
her fitment, and do me the kindness of our profession,
she has me her quirks, her reasons, her master reasons,
her prayers, her knees, that she would make a Puritan
of the devil, if he should cheapen a kiss of her.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
Faith I must ravish her, or she will disfurnish us
of all our Cavalleria, and make our swearers priests.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Now the pox upon her green sickness for me.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
Faith there is no way to be rid of it but by the
way to the pox. Here comes the Lord Lysimachus disguised.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
We should have both Lord and Lown, if the
peevish baggage would but give way to customers.

sp.speaker: Lysim.
sp.l: How now, how a dozen of virginities?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Now the Gods to bless your Honour.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.l: I am glad to see your Honour in good health.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p:
You may, so it is the better for you that your resorters
stand upon sound legs, how now? wholesome iniquity
have you, that a man may deal withal, and defy
the Surgeon?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
We have here one Sir, if she would, but
there never came her like in Meteline.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: If she would do the deeds of darkness thou wouldst say.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Your Honour knows what it is to say well enough.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Well, call forth, call forth.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
For flesh and blood Sir, white and red, you shall
see a rose, and she were a rose indeed, if she had but.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: What prithee?

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.l: O Sir, I can be modest.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p:
That dignities the renown of a Bawd, no less
than it gives a good report to a number to be chaste.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
Here comes that which grows to the stalk,
never plucked yet I can assure you.
Is she not a fair creature?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.p:
Faith she would serve after a long voyage at Sea,
Well there is for you, leave us.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
I beseech your Honour give me leave a word,
And I will have done presently.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: I beseech you do.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
First, I would have you note, this is an Honourable
man.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I desire to find him so, that I may worthily note him.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
Next he is the Governor of this country, and
a man whom I am bound to

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
If he govern the country you are bound to him
indeed, but how honourable he is in that, I know not.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
Pray you without any more virginal fencing,
will you use him kindly? he will line your apron with gold.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
What he will do graciously, I will thankfully
receive.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Have you done?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
My Lord she is not paced yet, you must take
some pains to work her to your manage, come we will
leave his Honour, and her together, go thy ways.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Now pretty one, how long have you been at this trade?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What trade Sir?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Why, I cannot name but I shall offend.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I cannot be offended with my trade, please you to name it.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: How long have you been of this profession?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Ever since I can remember.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p:
Did you go to it so young, were you a gamester
at five, or at seven?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Earlier too Sir, if now I be one.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.p:
Why? the house you dwell in proclaims you to
be a Creature of sale.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
Do you know this house to be a place of such
resort, and will come into it? I hear say you are of honourable
parts, and are the Governor of this place.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p:
Why, hath your principal made known unto
you who I am?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Who is my principal?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p:
Why, your herb-woman, she that sets seeds and
roots of shame and iniquity.
O you have heard something of my power, and so
stand aloft for more serious wooing, but I protest to thee
pretty one, my authority shall not see thee, or else look
friendly upon thee, come bring me to some private place:
Come, come.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
If you were born to honour, show it now, if put
upon you, make the judgment good, that thought you
worthy of it.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: How is this? how is this? some more, be sage.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
For me that am a maid, though most ungentle
Fortune haue placed me in this Sty, where since I came,
diseases have been sold dearer than Physic, that the
gods would set me free from this unhallowed place, though
they did change me to the meanest bird that flies in the
purer air.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p:
I did not think thou couldst have spoke so well,
never dreamt thou couldst , had I brought hither a corrupted
mind, thy speech had altered it, hold, here is
gold for thee, persevere in that clear way thou goest and
the gods strengthen thee.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: The good Gods preserve you.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p:
For me be you thought, that I came with no ill
intent, for to me the very doors and windows savour vilely,
fare thee well, thou art a piece of virtue, and I doubt not but
thy training hath been noble, hold, here is more gold for
thee, a curse upon him, die he like a thief that robs thee of
thy goodness, if thou dost hear from me it shall be for thy
good.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.l: I beseech your Honour one piece for me.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p:
Avaunt thou damned door-keeper, your house but 

for this virgin that  doth  prop it, 
would sink and overwhelm 
 you. Away.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
How is this? We must take another course with
you? if your peevish chastity, which is not worth a breakfast
in the cheapest country under the cope, shall undo a
whole household, let me be gelded like a spaniel, come your ways.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Whither would you have me?

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
I must haue your maidenhead taken off, or the
common hang-man shall execute it, come your way, we will have
no more Gentlemen driven away, come your ways I say.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: How now, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
Worse and worse mistress, she has here spoken
holy words to the Lord Lisimachus.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: O abominable.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
He makes our profession as it were to stink afore
the face of the gods.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Marie hang her up for ever.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
The Noble man would have dealt with her like
a Noble man, and she sent him away as cold as a Snowball,
saying his prayers too.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
Boult take her away, use her at thy pleasure, crack
the glass of her virginity, and make the rest malleable.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
And if she were a thornier piece of ground
than she is, she shall be ploughed.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Hark, hark you Gods.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
She conjures, away with her, would she had never
come within my doors, Marry hang you: she is born
to undo us, will you not go the way of womankind?
Marry come up my dish of chastity with rosemary and bays.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.l: Come mistress, come your way with me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Whither wilt thou have me?

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.l: To take from you the Jewel you hold so dear.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Prithee tell me one thing first.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.l: Come now your one thing.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What canst thou wish thine enemy to be.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
Why, I could wish him to be my master, or rather
my mistress.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
Neither of these are so bad as thou art, since they
do better thee in their command, thou holdest a place for
which the most pained fiend of hell would not in reputation
change: Thou art the damned doorkeeper to every
coistrel that comes enquiring for his Tib. To the choleric
fisting of every rogue, thy ear is liable, thy food is such
as hath been belched on by infected lungs.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p:
What would you have me do? go to the wars, would you?
where a man may serve seven years for the loss of a leg, and have
not money enough in the end to buy him a wooden one?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
Do anything but this thou doest, empty old
receptacles, or common-shores of filth, serve by indenture,
to the common hang-man, any of these ways are yet
better than this: for what thou professest, a Baboon could
he speak, would own a name too dear, that the gods would
safely deliver me from this place: here, here is gold for thee,
if that thy master would gain by me, proclaim that I can
sing, weave, sow, and dance, with other virtues, which I will keep
from boast, and will undertake all these to teach. I doubt
not but this populous City will yield many scholars.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.l: But can you teach all this you speak of?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
Prove that I cannot, take me home again,
And prostitute me to the basest groom that doth frequent
your house.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
Well I will see what I can do for thee: if I can
place thee I will.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: But amongst honest woman.

sp.speaker: Boult.
sp.p:
Faith my acquaintance lies little amongst them,
But since my master and mistress hath bought you, there is
no going but by their consent: therefore I will make them
acquainted with your purpose, and I doubt not but I shall
find them tractable enough. Come, I will do for thee what
I can, come your ways.

sp.l: Marina thus the Brothel scapes, and chances
Into an Honest-house our Story says:
She sings like one immortal, and she dances
As Goddess-like to her admired lays.
Deep clerks she dumbs, and with her needle composes,
Natures own shape, of bud, bird, branch, or berry.
That even her art sisters the natural Roses
Her Inkle, Silk Twine, with the rubied Cherry,
That pupils lacks she none of noble race,
Who pour their bounty on her: and her gain
She gives the cursed Bawd, here we her place,
And to her Father turn our thoughts again,
Where we left him on the Sea, we there him left,
Where driven before the winds, he is arrived
Here where his daughter dwells, and on this coast,
Suppose him now at Anchor: the City strived
God Neptunes Annual feast to keep, from whence
Lysimachus our Tyrian Ship espies,
His banners Sable, trimmed with rich expense,
And to him in his Barge with former hies,
In your supposing once more put your sight,
Of heavy Pericles, think this his Bark:
Where what is done in action, more if might
Shall be discovered, please you sit and hark.

div1.stage: Exit. Enter Helicanus, to him 2. Saylers.

sp.speaker: 1. Say.
sp.p:
Where is Lord Helicanus? he can resolve you,
O here he is Sir, there is a barge put off from Metaline and
in it is Lysimachus the Governor, who craves to come aboard,
what is your will?

sp.speaker: Helly.
sp.l: That he have his, call up some Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Ho Gentlemen, my Lord calls.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Doth your Lordship call?

sp.speaker: Helli.
sp.p:
Gentlemen there is some of worth would come
aboard, I pray greet him fairly.

sp.speaker: 1. Say.
sp.p:
Sir, this is the man that can in aught you would
resolve you.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Hail reverent Sir, the Gods preserve you.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p:
And you to outlive the age I am, and die as I
would do.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p:
You wish me well, being on shore, honouring of
Neptunes triumphs, seeing this goodly vessel ride before
us, I made to it, to know of whence you are.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: First what is your place?

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.l: I am the Governor of this place you lie before.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p:
Sir our vessel is of Tyre, in it the King, a man,
who for this three months hath not spoken to any one,
nor taken sustenance, but to prorogue his grief.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Upon what ground is his distemperature?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p:
It would be too tedious to repeat, but the main
grief springs from the loss of a beloved daughter and a wife.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: May we not see him?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p:
You may, but bootless. Is your sight, he will not
speak to any, yet let me obtain my wish.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Behold him, this was a goodly person.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p:
Till the disaster that one mortal wight drove him
to this.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p:
Sir King all hail, the Gods preserve you, hail
royal sir.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: It is in vain, he will not speak to you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
Sir we have a maid in Metiline, I durst wager would
win some words of him.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p:
It is well bethought, she questionless with her sweet
harmony, and other chosen attractions, would allure and
make a battery through his defend parts, which now are
midway stopped, she is all happy as the fairest of all, and her
fellow maids, now upon the leafy shelter that abuts
against the Islands side.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p:
Sure all effectless, yet nothing we will omit that
bears recoveries name. But since your kindness we have
stretched thus far, let us beseech you, that for our gold
we may provision have, wherein we are not destitute for
want, but weary for the staleness.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p:
O sir, a courtesy, which if we should deny, the most
just God for every graft would send a Caterpillar, and so
inflict our Province: yet once more let me entreat to
know at large the cause of your kings sorrow.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.p: Sit sir, I will recount it to you, but see I am prevented.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: O here is the Lady that I sent for,
Welcome fair one, is it not a goodly present?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: She is a gallant Lady.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p:
She is such a one, that were I well assured
Came of a gentle kind, and noble stock, I do wish
No better choice, and think me rarely to wed,
sp.l: Fair on all goodness that consists in beauty,
sp.p:
Expect even here, where is a kingly patient,
If that thy prosperous and artificial fate,
Can draw him but to answer thee in aught,
Thy sacred Physic shall receive such pay,
As thy desires can wish.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Sir I will use my utmost skill in his recovery, provided
that none but I and my companion maid be suffered
to come near him.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Come, let us leave her, and the Gods make her prosperous.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Mark he your Music?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No nor looked on us.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: See she will speak to him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hail sir, my Lord lend ear.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Hum, ha.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I am a maid, my Lord, that never before invited
eyes, but have been gazed on like a Comet: She speaks
my Lord, that may be, hath endured a grief might equal
yours, if both were justly weighed, though wayward fortune
did malign my state, my derivation was from ancestors,
who stood equivalent with mighty Kings, but time hath
rooted out my parentage, and to the world, and awkward
casualties, bound me in servitude, I will desist, but there is
something glows upon my cheek, and whispers in mine
ear, go not till he speak.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
My fortunes, parentage, good parentage, to equal
mine, was it not thus, what say you?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p:
I said my Lord, if you did know my parentage,
you would not do me violence.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
I do think so, pray you turn your eyes upon me,
you are like something that, what Country women hear of
these shows?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
No, nor of any shows, yet I was mortally brought
forth, and am no other than I appear.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
I am great with woe, and shall deliver weeping: my
dearest wife was like this maid, and such a one my daughter
might have been: My Queens square brows, her
stature to an inch, as wandlike-straight, as silver voiced,
her eyes as Jewel-like, and caste as richly, in pace an other
Iuno. Who starves the ears she feeds, and makes
them hungry, the more she gives them speech, Where do
you live?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Where I am but a stranger; from the deck, you
may discern the place.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Where were you bred? and how achieved you these
endowments which you make more rich to owe?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
If I should tell my history, it would seem like
lies disdained in the reporting.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Prithee speak, falseness cannot come from thee,
for thou lookest modest as justice, and thou seemest a Pallas
for the crowned truth to dwell in; I will believe thee and make
senses credit thy relation, to points that seem impossible,
for thou lookest like one I loved indeed: what were thy
friends? didst thou not stay when I did push thee back,
which was, when I perceived thee that thou camest from
good descending.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So indeed I did.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Report thy parentage, I think thou saidst thou hadst
been tossed from wrong to injury, and that thou thoughts
thy griefs might equal mine, if both were opened.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Some such thing I said, and said no more, but what
my thoughts did warrant me was likely.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Tell thy story, if thine considered prove the thousand
part of my endurance, thou art a man, and I have
suffered like a girl, yet thou dost look like patience,
gazing on Kings graves, and smiling extremity out of
act, what were thy friends? how lost thou thy name,
my most kind Virgin? recount I do beseech thee, Come
sit by me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My name is Marina.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
O I am mocked, and thou by some incensed God
sent hither to make the world to laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Patience good sir: or here I will cease.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Nay I will be patient: thou little knowest how thou
dost startle me to call thyself Marina.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
The name was given me by one that had some
power, my father, and a King.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: How, a Kings daughter, and called Marina ?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
You said you would believe me, but not to be a
troubler of your peace, I will end here.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: But are you flesh and blood?
Have you a working pulse, and are no Fairy?
Motion well, speak on, where were you born?
And wherefore called Marina?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Called Marina, for I was born at sea.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: At sea, what mother?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
My mother was the daughter of a King, who died
the minute I was born, as my good Nurse Licherida hath
oft delivered weeping.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
O stop there a little, this is the rarest dream
That ever dulled sleep did mock sad fools withal,
This cannot be my daughter, buried; well, where were you
bred? I will hear you more to the bottom of your story,
and never interrupt you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You scorn, believe me it were best I did give over.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
I will believe you by the syllable of what you shall
deliver, yet give me leave, how came you in these parts?
where were you bred?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
The King my father did in Tharsus leave me,
Till cruel Cleon with his wicked wife,
Did seek to murther me: and having wooed a villain,
To attempt it, who having drawn to do it,
A crew of Pirates came and rescued me,
Brought me to Metaline,
But good sir whither will you have me? why do you weep?
It may be you think me an imposture, no good faith: I
am the daughter to King Pericles, if good king Pericles be.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Ho, Hellicanus?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Calls my Lord.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Thou art a grave and noble Counsellor,
sp.p:
Most wise; in general, tell me if thou canst, what this maid
is, or what is like to be, that thus hath made me
weep.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
I know not, but here is the Regent sir of Metaline,
speaks nobly of her.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: She never would tell her parentage,
Being demanded, that, she would sit still and weep.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
O Hellicanus, strike me honoured sir, give me a
gash, put me to present pain, least this great sea of joys rushing
upon me, over-bear the shores of my mortality, and
drown me with their sweetness: O come hither,
thou that begetst him that did thee beget,
Thou that wast born at sea, buried at Tharsus,
And found at sea again, O Hellicanus,
Down on thy knees, thank the holy Gods as loud
As thunder threatens us; this is Marina.
What was thy mothers name? tell me, but that
for truth can never be confirmed enough,
Though doubts did ever sleep.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: First sir, I pray what is your title?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
I am Pericles of Tyre; but tell me now my
Drowned Queens name, as in the rest you said,
Thou hast been God-like perfect, the heir of kingdoms,
And an other like to Pericles thy father.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
Is it no more to be your daughter, than to say, my
mothers name was Thaisa. Thaisa was my mother, who did
end the minute I began.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p:
Now blessing on thee, rise thou art my child.
Give me fresh garments, mine own Hellicanus, she is not
dead at Tharsus as she should have been by savage Cleon;
she shall tell thee all, when thou shalt kneel, and justify in
knowledge, she is thy very Princes, who is this?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Sir, it is the governor of Metaline, who hearing of
your melancholy state, did come to see you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I embrace you, give me my robes.
I am wild in my beholding, O heavens bless my girl,
But hark what Music tell, Hellicanus my Marina,
Tell him over point by point, for yet he seems to dote.
How, sure you are my daughter; but what music?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: My Lord I hear none.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: None, the Music of the Spheres, lift my Marina.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: It is not good to cross him, give him way.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Rarest sounds, do ye not hear?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Music my Lord? I hear.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Most heavenly Music.
It nips me unto listening, and thick slumber
Hangs upon mine eyes, let me rest.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p:
A Pillow for his head, so leave him all.
Well my companion friends, if this but answer to my just
belief, I will well remember you.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p:
My Temple stands in Ephesus;
Hie thee thither, and do upon mine Altar sacrifice;
There when my maiden priests are met together, before the
people all, reveal how thou at sea didst lose thy wife; to
mourn thy crosses with thy daughters; call, and give them
repetition to the like; or perform my bidding, or thou livest
in woe: do it, and happy, by my silver bow; awake and
tell thy dream.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Celestial Dian, Goddess Argentine,
I will obey thee: Hellicanus.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
Lys
sp.l: Sir, with all my heart, and when you come a shore,
I have another sleight.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
You shall prevail were it to woo my daughter, for
it seems you have been noble towards her.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: Sir, lend me your arm.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Come my Marina.

sp.speaker: Gower.
sp.l: Now our sands are almost run,
More a little, and then dumb.
This my last boon give me;
For such kindness must relieve me:
That you aptly will suppose,
What pageantry, what feats, what shows,
What minstrelsy, and pretty din,
The Regent made in Metalin.
To greet the King, so he thrived,
That he is promised to be wived
To fair Marina, but in no wise,
Till he had done his sacrifice.
As Dian bad, whereto being bound,
The Interim pray, you all confound.
In feathered briefness sails are filled;
And wishes fall out as they are wild;
At Ephesus the Temple see,
Our King and all his company.
That he can hither come so soon,
Is by your fancies thankful doom.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Hail Dian, to perform thy just command,
I here confess myself the King of Tyre;
Who frighted from my country did wed at Pentapolis, the
fair Thaisa, at Sea in child-bed died she, but brought forth a
Maid child called Marina whom, O Goddess wears yet thy
silver livery; she at Tharsus was nursed with Cleon, who at
fourteen years he sought to murder, but her better stars
brought her to Meteline, against whose shore riding, her
Fortunes brought the maid aboard us, where by her
own most clear remembrance, she made known herself
my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p:
Voice and favour, you are, you are, O royal
Pericles.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What means the mum? she dies, help Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ceri.
sp.p:
Noble Sir, if you have told Dianaes Altar
true, this is your wife?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Reverent appearer no, I threw her overboard
with these very arms.

sp.speaker: Ce.
sp.l: Upon this coast, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: It is most certain.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.p:
Look to the Lady, O she is but overjoyed,
Early in blustering morn this Lady was thrown upon
this shore.
I oped the coffin, found there rich Jewels, recovered
her, and placed her here in Dianaes temple.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: May we see them?

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.p:
Great Sir, they shall be brought you to my house,
whither I invite you; look Thaisa is recovered.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p:
O let me look if he be none of mine, my sanctity
will to my sense bend no licentious ear, but curb
it spite of seeing: O my Lord are you not Pericles? like
him you spake, like him you are; did you not name a tempest,
a birth, and death?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: The voice of dead Thaisa.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: That Thaisa am I, supposed dead and drowned.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p:
Now I know you better; when we with tears
parted Pentapolis, the king my father gave you such a ring.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
This, this, no more, you gods, your present kindness
makes my past miseries sports; you shall do well that
on the touching of her lips I may melt, and no more be
seen; O come, be buried a second time within these arms.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: My heart leaps to be gone into my mothers bosom.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Look who kneels here, flesh of thy flesh Thaisa,
thy burden at the Sea, and called Marina, for she was yielded
there.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: Blessed, and mine own.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Hail Madam, and my Queen.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: I know you not.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
You have heard me say when I did fly from
Tyre, I left behind an ancient substitute, can you remember
what I called the man, I have named him oft.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.l: It was Hellicanus then.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Still confirmation, embrace him dear Thaisa, this
is he, now do I long to hear how you were found? how
possibly preserved? and who to thank (besides the gods)
for this great miracle?

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p:
Lord Cerimon, my Lord; this man through whom
the Gods have shown their power, that can from first to
last resolve you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Reverent Sir, the gods can have no mortal officer
more like a god than you, will you deliver how this dead
Queen relives?

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.p:
I will my Lord, beseech you first, go with me
to my house, where shall be shown you all was found with
her. How she came placed here in the Temple, no
needful thing omitted.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Pure Dian bless thee for thy vision, and will offer
night oblations to thee Thaisa, this Prince, the fair betrothed
of your daughter, shall marry her at Pentapolis, and
now this ornament makes me look dismal, will I clip to
form, and what this fourteen years no razor touched, to
grace thy marriage-day, I will beautify.

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p:
Lord Cerimon hath letters of good credit. Sir,
my father is dead.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Heavens make a Star of him, yet there my
Queen, we will celebrate their Nuptials, and ourselves
will in that kingdom spend our following days, our son
and daughter shall in Tyrus reign.
Lord Cerimon we do our longing stay,
sp.l: To hear the rest untold, Sir lead us the way.
In Antiochus and his daughter you have heard
Of monstrous lust, the due and just reward:
In Pericles his Queen and Daughter seen,
Although assailed with Fortune fierce and keen.
Virtue preferred from fell destructions blast,
Lead on by heaven, and drowned with joy at last.
In Helycanus may you well descry,
A figure of truth, of faith, of loyalty:
In reverend Cerimon there well appears,
The worth that learned charity aye wears.
For wicked Cleon and his wife, when Fame
Had spread his cursed deed, the honour's name
Of Pericles, to rage the City turn,
That him and his they in his Palace burn:
The gods for murder seemed so content,
To punish, although not done, but meant.
So on your Patience evermore attending,
New joy wait on you, here our play has ending.
